sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Plant a watch there, be very careful sirs, the rest with us.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: The heavy night grows to her depth of quiet, 'tis about mid darkness.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mine chamber is hard by, ick sall bring you to it presant ment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Deep silence. on

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Within Wa, ha, ha,Ex.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
It was his voice, 'tis he: he sups with his cupping glasses. 'tis late, he must pass this way: I'll ha' him, I'll ha' my fine
boy, my worshipful Cocledemoy, I'll moy him, he shall be hanged in lousy linen, I'll hire some sectary to make him an heretic before he die? And when he is dead I'll piss on his grave.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Ah my fine punks, good night, Frank, frailty, frail a Fraile-hall? Bonus noches my ubiquitari.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Beware polling and shaving sir.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: A wolf, a wolf, a wolf,Exit. Cocledemoy

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Here's something yet, a cloak, a cloak, yet I'll after, he cannot scape the watch, I'll hang him if I have any mercy ▪ I'll slice him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Who goes there? come before the constable.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Bread a God constable, you are a watch for the devil. Honest men are robbed under your nose, there's a false knave in the habit of a vintner, set upon me, he would have had my purse, but I took me to my heels: yet he got my cloak, a plain stuff cloak poor, yet 'twill serve to hang him? 'tis my loss, poor man that I am.

div.stage: Enter Mulligrub running with cocledemoys cloak.

sp.p: Masters, we must watch better, is't not strange that knaves, drunkards, and thieves, should be a broad, and yet we of the watch, scriveners, smiths, and tailors, never stir.
Hark, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: An honest man and a citizen.
Appear, appear, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: A simple vintner.
A vintner ha, and simple, draw nearer, nearer: here's the cloak.
I master vintner we know you, a plain stuff cloak: 'tis it.
Right, come: o thou varlet, dost not thou know that the wicked cannot scape the eyes of the constable?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What means this violence, as I am an honest man I took the cloak.
As you are a knave, you took the cloak, we are your witnesses for that.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: But hear me, hear me, I'll tell you what I am.
A thief you are.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I tell you my name is mullegrub.
I will grub you, in with him to the stocks, there let him sit tell tomorrow morning that justice quodlibet may examine him.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Why but I tell thee.
Why but I tell thee, we'll tell thee now.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Am I not mad, am I not an ass,
Why scabs, god's foot: let me out.

sp.p: Ay, ay, let him prate, he shall find matter in us scabs I warrant: gods so, what good members of the common wealth, do we prove.
Prithee peace, let's remember our duties, and let go sleep, in the fear of God. Exeunt.

div.stage: Having left Mullegrub in the stocks.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Who goes there: I lo, ho, ho: zounds shall I run mad, lose my wits: shall I be hanged, hark: who goes there? Do not fear to be poor mullegrub, thou hast a sure stock now.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.l: The night grows old,
And many a cuckold is now wha, ha, ha, ho,
Maids on their backs,
Dream of sweet smacks, and warm: woe, ho, ho, ho,
I must go comfort my venerable mullegrub, I must
Fiddle him till he fist: fough:
Maids in your night-rails,
Look well to your light
Keep close your locks,
And down your smocks,
Keep a broad eye
And a close thigh, excellent, excellent, who's there?
Now lord, lord, (Master mullegrub) deliver us: what does your worship in the stocks? I pray come out sir.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Zounds man I tell thee I am locked.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p:
Locked: oh world: oh men: oh time: oh night: that canst not
discern virtue, and wisdom, and one of the common counsel: what is your worship in for?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: For (A plague on't) suspicion of felony.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Nay, and it be but such a trifle, lord I could weep, to see your good worship in this taking: your worship has been a good friend to me, and though you have forgotten me, yet I knew your wife before she was married, and since I have found your worsh. door open and I have knocked, and God knows what I have saved: and do I live to see your worship stocked?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Honest Belman, I perceive thou knowest me, I prithee call the watch. Inform the constable of my reputation, that I may no longer abide in this shameful habitation, and hold thee, all I have about me.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: 'Tis more than I deserve sir: let me alone for your delivery.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Do, and then let me alone with Cockledemoy, I'll moy him.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Maids in your: master Constable, who's that ith' stocks?
One for a robbery: one mullegrub, he calls himself. Mullegrub? Belman, knowest thou him?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Know him: oh master const. what good service have you done. Know him? He's a strong thief, his house has been suspected for a bawdy tavern a great while: and a receipt for cutpurses, 'tis most certain: he has been long in the black book, and is he ta'en now?
By’r lady my masters we'll not trust the stocks with him, we'll have him to the justices, get a mittimus to Newgate presently. Come sir, come on sir.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha: does your rascalship yet know my worship in the end?
Ay, the end of your worship we know.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Ha, goodman constable, here's an honest fellow can tell you what I am?
'Tis true sir, you're a strong thief he says on his own knowledge: bind fast, bind fast, we know you: we'll trust no stocks with you. Away with him to the jail instantly.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Why but dost hear Belman, rogue, rascal, gods
why but? The constable drags away mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: Why but; wha ha ha, excellent, excellent, ha my fine Cocledemoy, my vintner fists, I'll make him fart crackers before I ha' done with him; tomorrow is the day of judgement.
Afore the lord God my knavery grows unperegall, 'tis time to take a nap, until half an hour hence: God give your worship music, content, and rest.

div.head: Actus quintus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Franchischina, sir Lyonel, Tissefeu, with officers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You been very velcom to mine shambra.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: But how know ye, how are ye assure both of the deed, and of his suit return.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O myn-here. Ick sall tell you, metre Malhereux
Came all breathless running a my shambra
His sword all bloody: he tell a me he had kill Frevile,
And pred a me to conceal him:
Ick flatter him, bid bring moneys, he should live and lie vid me,
He went whilst ick (Me hope vidout sins) out of mine
Much love to Frevile betray him.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Fear not, 'tis well: good works get grace for sin.
sp.stage: She conceals them behind the curtain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dear, peace, rest dear, so softly, all go in:
De net is laie, now sal ick be revenge.
If dat me knew a dog dat Frevile love,
Me would poison him, for know de deepest hell
As a revenging woman's, naught so fell.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ho cousin Francke, the party you wot of, m. Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bid him come up, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O min here man, a dear liver love,
Mine ten tousant times velcom love,
ha, by mine trat, you been de just, vat sall me say:
Vat seet honey name sall I call you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Any from you is pleasure. Come my loving
Prettiness, where's thy chamber?
I long to touch your sheets.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, no, not yet mine sweetest soft-lipped love:
You sall not gulp down all delights at once:
Be min trat, dis all-fles-lovers, dis ravenous wenches
Dat sallow all down hole, vill have all at one bit,
Fie, fie, fie, be min fait day do eat
Comfits vid spoons.
No, no, I'll make you chew your pleasure vit love,
"De more degrees and steps, de more delight,
" de more endeared is de pleasure hight.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What your a learned wanton, and proceed by art?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go little wag, pleasure should have a
Crane's long neck, to relish de ambrosia of
Delight.
And ick pre de tel me, for me loves to hear of manhood
Very much, isait: ick prede (Vat vas me a saying)
O, ick prede tell a me:
How did you kill a metre Frevile?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why quarreled a set purpose, drew him out, singled him, and having th'advantage of my sword and might, ran him through and through.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat did you vid him van he was sticken?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I dragged him by the heels to the next wharf and spurned him in the river.

div.stage: Those in ambush rusheth forth and takes him.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Seize, seize him: oh monstrous? O ruthless villain?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: What mean you gentlemen? by heaven,

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Speak not of any thing that's good.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your errors gives you passion: Frevile lives.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Thy own lips say, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Let me die if at Shatewe's the jeweller, he lives not safe untouched.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Mean time to strictest guard, to sharpest prison.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: No rudeness gentlemen: I'll go undragged.
O wicked, wicked devil. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.l: Sir, the day of trial is this morn,
Let's prosecute the sharpest rigor, and severest end:
"Good men are cruel, when they're vices friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.l: Woman we thank thee, with no empty hand,
Strumpets are fit, fit for something. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ay, for hell: oh thou unreprievable, beyond all
Measure of grace damned immediately:
That things of beauty created for sweet use:
Soft comfort, and as the very music of life,
Custom should make so unutterably hellish?
O heaven, what difference is in women, and their life?
What man, but worthy name of man:
Would leave the modest pleasures of a lawful bed:
The holy union of two equal hearts
Mutually holding either dear as health,
The undoubted issues, joys of chaste sheets,
The unfeigned embrace of sober ignorance:
To twine the unhealthful loins of common loves,
The prostituted impudence of things.
Senseless like those by cataracts of Nile,
"Their use so vile, takes away sense how vile,
" to love a creature, made of blood and hell,
"Whose use makes weak, whose company doth shame,
" whose bed doth beggar: issue doth defame.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Metre Frevile live: ha, ha, live at mestre Shatewe's:
Much at metre Shatew's. Frevile is dead. Malhereux sall hang,
And sweet devil, dat Beatrice would but run mad, dat
She would but run mad, den me would dance and sing,
Metre don Dubon, me pre ye now go to mestres
Beatrice, tell her Frevile is sure dead, and dat he
Curse herself especially, for dat he was
Sticked in her quarrel, swearing in his last gasp,
Dat if it had been in mine quarrels,
'Twould never have grieved him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Prede do, and say any ting dat vil vex her.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Let me alone to vex her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Vil you, vil you make a her run mad? here take
Dis ring, sea me scorn to wear any ting dat washers,
Or his: I prede torment her, ick cannot love her,
She honest and virtuous forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Is she so? O vile creature? then let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Vat. Vil you make a her mad? seet by min trat,
Be pretta servan, bush, ick sall go to bet now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Mischief whether wilt thou? O thou tearless woman?
How monstrous is thy devil,
The end of hell as thee.
How miserable were it to be virtuous, if thou couldst prosper?
I'll to my love, the faithful Beatrice,
She has wept enough, and faith dear soul too much.
But yet how sweet it is to think
How dear ones life was to his love: how mourned his death.
'Tis joy not to be expressed with breath:
But oh let him that would such passion drink,
Be quiet of his speech, and only think. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Sister, cannot a woman kill herself? Is it not lawful to die when we should not live?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: O sister 'tis a question not for us, we must do what God will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What God will? Alas, can torment be his glory, or our grief his pleasure? Does not the nurse's nipple juiced over with wormwood, bid the child it should not suck? And does not heaven when it hath made our breath bitter unto us, say we should not live? O my best sister: to suffer wounds when one may scape this rod, is against nature, that is against God.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Good sister do not make me weep: sure Frevile was not false: I'll gauge my life that strumpet out of craft
And some close second end hath maliced him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: O sister if he were not false, whom have I lost?
If he were: what grief to such unkindness,
From head to foot I am all misery:
only in this, some justice I have found
My grief is like my love, beyond all bound. Enter nurse

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: My servant, master Cacature desires to visit you,

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: For grief's sake keep him out, his discourse is like the long word, honorificabilitudinitatibus: a great deal
Of sound and no sense: his company is like a parenthesis.
To a discourse you may admit it, or leave it out, it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: By your leave sweet creatures.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Sir, all I can yet say of you, is, you are uncivil.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You must deny it: by your sorrow's leave,
I bring some music, to make sweet your grief,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Whate'er you please: oh break my heart
Canst thou yet pant? O dost thou yet seruive,
Thou didst not love him, if thou now canst live ▪

div.l: O love, how strangely sweet
Are thy weak passions,
That love and joy 〈…〉
In self same fashions.
O who can tell
The cause why this should move ▪
But only this,
No reason, ask of love.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Hold, peace, the ge● 〈…〉 o my best sister.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ha, get you gone, close the doors: my Beatrice,
Cursed be my indiscreet trials: oh my immeasurably loving.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: She stirs, give air, she breathes.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Where am I, ha? how have I slipped off life?
Am I in heaven? O my lord, though not loving
By our eternal being, yet give me leave
To rest by thy dear side: am I not in heaven?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O eternally much laved, recollect your spirits.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Ha, you do speak, I do see you, I do live,
I would not die now: let me not burst with wonder.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Call up your blood, I live to honour you,
As the admired glory of your sex.
Nor ever hath my love been false to you.
Only I presumed to try your faith too much,
For which I most am grieved.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Brother; I must be plain with you, you have wronged us.
I am not so covetous to deny it,
But yet when my discourse hath stayed your quaking,
You will be smoother lipped: and the delight
And satisfaction which we all have got,
Under these strange disguisings, when you know,
You will be mild and quiet, forget at last,
"It is much joy to think on sorrows past.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Do you then live? and are you not untrue?
Let me not die with joy, pleasure's more extreme:
Then grief, there's nothing sweet to man but mean.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Heaven cannot be too gracious to such goodness, I shall discourse to you the several chances, but hark I must yet rest disguised, the sudden close of many drifts now meet,
"Where pleasure hath some profit, art is sweet. Enter Tisefeu.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: News, news, news, news.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Oysters, oysters, oysters, oysters.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Why, is not this well now? Is not this better than louring, and pouting, and puling, which is hateful to the living, and vain to the dead? Come, come, you must live by the quick, when all is done, and for my own part, let my wife laugh at me when I am dead, so she'll smile upon me whilst I live, but to see a woman whine, and yet keep her eyes dry mourn, and yet keep her cheeks fat: nay, to see a woman claw her husband by the feet when he is dead, that would have scratched him by the face when he was living: this now is somewhat ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Lord how you prate.

sp.speaker: Tis.
sp.p: And yet I was afraid i'faith that I should ha' seen a garland on this beauty's hearse, but time, truth, experience, and variety, are great doers with women.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But what's the news? the news I pray you?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: I pray you? ne'er pray me: for by your leave you may command me. This 'tis: the public sessions which this day is past, hath doomed to death ill fortuned Malhereux.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: But sir, we heard he offered to make good,
That Frevile lived at Shatew's the jewellers.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: And that 'twas but a plot betwixt them two.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.l: O ay, ay, he gaged his life with it, but know
When all approached the test, Shatew's divide
He saw or heard of any such complot,
Or of Frevill: so that his own defence,
Appeared so false, that like a madman's sword,
He stroke his own heart, he hath the course of law
And instantly must suffer: but the jest
(If hanging be a jest) as many make it)
Is to take notice of one mullegrub, a sharking vintner.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What of him sir.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Nothing but hanging, the whoreson slave is mad before he hath lost his senses.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Was his fact clear and made apparent sir?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.l: No faith suspicions, for 'twas thus protested
A cloak was stolen, that cloak he had, he had it
Himself confessed by force, the rest of his defence
The choler of a justice wronged in wine,
Joined with malignance of some hasty jurors,
Whose wit was lighted by the justice nose, the knave was cast,
But lord to hear his moan, his prayers, his wishes,
His zeal ill timed, and his words unpitied,
Would make a dead man rise and smile,
Whilst he observed how fear can make men vile.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Shall we go meet the execution?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I shall be ruled by you.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.l: By my troth a rare motion, you must haste,
For malefactors goes like the world upon wheels.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Will you man us, you shall be our guide to Frevile.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Ha servant? Zounds I am no companion for panders ▪ your best make him your love.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: So will I sir, we must live by the quick you say.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.l: 'Sdeath a virtue, what a damned things this?
Whole trust fair faces, tears, and vows, 'sdeath not I,
She is a woman, that is, she can lie.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Come, come, turn not a man of time, to make all ill,
Whose goodness you conceive not, since the worst of chance
Is to crave grace for 〈…〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: So, I ha' lost my sergeant in an ecliptic mist, drunk, horrible drunk, he is fine: so now will I fit myself, I hope this habit will do me no harm, I am an honest man already: fit, fit, fit as a punk's tail, that serves everybody : by this time my vintner thinks of nothing but hell and sulphur, he farts fire and brimstone already, hang tostes, the execution approacheth.

div.stage: Enter sir Lyonell: sir Hubert, Malhereux piniond, Tysefeu, Beatrice, Frevile, Crisp. Francischina, and halberds.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do not blush, although condemned by laws,
No kind of death is shameful but the cause:
Which I do know is none, and yet my lust
Hath made the one (Although not cause) most just.
May I not be reprieved? Frevile is but mislodged,
Some lethargy hath seized him, no, much malice,
Do not lay blood upon your souls with good intents,
Men may do ill and law sometime repents.

div.stage: Cockledemoy picks malhereuxes pocket of his purse.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Sir, sir, prepare, vain is all lewd defence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: "Conscience was law: but now law's conscience,
My endless peace is made, and to the poor,
My purse, my purse.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: I sir, and it shall please you the poor has your purse a●.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You are a Welyman,
But now thou source of devils, o how I loath
The very memory of that I adored,
He that's of fair blood, well meant, of good breeding,
Best famed, of sweet acquaintance and true friends ▪
And would with desperate impudence lose all these,
And hazard landing at this fatal shore,
Let him never kill, nor steal, but love a whore,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: De man dose rave, tinck a got, tinck a got, and bid d●●●●lesh, de world, and the dible farewell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Farewell. Frevile discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vat is't you sea, ha?

sp.speaker: Fre ▪
sp.l: Sir your pardon, with my this defence,
Do not forget protested violence
Of your low affections no requests,
No arguments of reason, no known danger.
No assured wicked bloodiness,
Could draw your heart from this damnation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why stay.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Unprosperous devil, vat sall me do now.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Therefore to force you from the truer danger,
I wrought the feigned, suffering this fair devil,
In shaps of woman to make good her plot,
And knowing that the hook was deeply fast,
I gave her line at will, till with her own vain strivings,
See here she's tired: oh thou comely damnation?
Dost think that vice is not to be withstood,
Oh what is woman merely made of blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: You maze us all, let us not be lost in darkness?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: All shall be lighted, but this time and place
Forbids longer speech, only what you can think
Has been extremely ill is only hers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: To severest prison with her, with what heart canst live? What eyes behold a face?

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: Ick vil not speak, torture, torture your fill,
For me am worse than hanged, me ha' lost my will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: To the extremest whip and jail.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Frolique, how is it sirs?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I am myself, how long was't ere I could
Persuade my passion to grow calm to you?
Rich sense makes good bad language, and a friend
Should weigh no action, but the actions end.
I am now worthy yours, when before
The beast of man, loose blood distempered us,
"He that lust rules cannot be virtuous.

div.stage: Enter Mullegrub mistress Mullegrub and officers.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: On afore there, room for the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I pray you do not lead me to execution through Cheapside, I owe m. Burnish the goldsmith money, and I fear he'll set a sergeant on my back for it.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Trouble not your sconce my Christian brothers, but have an eye unto the main chance, I will warrant your shoulders, as for your neck Plinius secundus, or Marcus Tullius Cycero, or somebody it is says, that a three fold cord is hardly broken.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Well, I am not the first honest man that hath been cast away, and I hope shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: O sir, have a good stomach and maws, you shall have a joyful supper.

sp.speaker: Muly.
sp.p: In troth I have no stomach to it, and it please you take my trencher ▪ I use to fast at nights.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mul.
sp.p: O husband, I little thought you should have come to think on God thus soon: nay and you had been hanged deservedly, it would never have grieved me, I have known of many honest innocent men have been hanged deservedly, but to be cast away for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: Good woman hold your peace, your prittles and your prattles your bibbles and your babbles, for I pray you hear me in private, I am a widower, and you are almost a widow, shall I be welcome to your houses, to your tables, and your other things.

sp.speaker: Mist Mul.
sp.p: I have a piece of mutton and a featherbed for you at all times, I pray make haste.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I do here make my confession, if I owe any man any thing, I do heartily forgive him: if any man owe me any thing, let him pay my wife.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: I will look to your wife's payment I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: And now good yoke-fellow leave thy poor mulligrub.

sp.speaker: Mist Mul.
sp.p: Nay then I were unkind i'faith, I will not leave you until I have seen you hang.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: But brothers, brothers, you must think of your sins and iniquities, you have been a broacher of profane vessels, you have made us drink of the juice of the whore of Babylon, for whereas good ale, perrys, bragets, syders, and metheglins, was the true ancient British and Trojan drinks, you ha' brought in popish wines, Spanish wines, French wines, tam marti quam mercurio, both muscadine and malmsey, to the subversion, staggering, and sometimes overthrow of many a good christian: you ha' been a great jumbler, oh remember the sins of your nights, for your night works ha' been unsavoury in the taste of your customers.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: I confess, I confess, and I forgive as I would be forgiven, do you know one Cocledemoy?

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: O very well: know him? an honest man he is and a comely, an upright dealer with his neighbours, and their wives speak good things of him.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Well, wheresoe'er he is, or whatsoever he is, I'll take it on my death he's the cause of my hanging, I heartily forgive him, and if he would come forth he might save me, for he only knows the why, and the wherefore.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p: You do from your hearts, and midrifs, and entrails forgive him than you will not let him rot in rusty irons, procure him to be hanged in lousy linen without a song, and after he is dead piss on his grave.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: That hard heart of mine has procured all this, but I forgive as I would be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hang toasts my worsh.

sp.speaker: Mulli.
sp.p: Behold thy Cocledemoy, my fine vintner, my castrophomicall fine boy: behold and see.

sp.speaker: Tyss.
sp.p: Bliss, a the blessed, who would but look for 2. knaves here?

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: No knave wor. friend, no knave, for observe honest Cocledemoy restores whatsoever he has got, to make you know, that whatsoever he has done, has been only euphoniae gratia, for wit's sake: I acquit this vintner as he has acquitted me, all has been done for emphases of wit my fine boy, my worshipful friends.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Go you are a flattering knave.

sp.speaker: Cocl.
sp.p: I am so, 'tis a good thriving trade, it coms forward better than the 7. liberal sciences, or the nine Cardinal virtues, which may well appear in this, you shall never have flattering knave turn courtier: and yet I have read of many courtiers that have turned flattering knaves.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Wast even but so, why then all's well?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I could even weep for joy.

sp.speaker: Mist, Mul.
sp.p: I could weep to, but God knows for what.

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Hers another tack to be given, your son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hub.
sp.p: Is't possible, heart I, all my heart, will you be joined here?

sp.speaker: Tys.
sp.p: Yes faith father, marriage and hanging are spun both in one hour.

sp.speaker: Cocle.
sp.p:
Why then my worsh. good friends I bid myself most heartily welcome to your merry nuptials, and wanton jigga-joggies and now my very fine Heliconian gallants, and you my worsh. friends in the middle region:
If with content our hurtless mirth hath been,
Let your pleased minds as our much care hath been:
For he shall find that slights such trivial wit,
'Tis easier to reprove then better it:
We scorn to fear, and yet we fear to swell,
We do not hope 'tis best: 'tis all, 〈…〉Exeunt

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
